description: From Italian gamba (“leg”). Doublet of gamba, jamb, and gamb.

entries.meaning: (slang) A person's leg, especially an attractive woman's leg.
examples: The women's-liberation movement of the late sixties and the seventies – the so-called second wave of feminism – introduced Americans to the notion that their mothers and sisters and daughters ought not to be "objectified": that there was something wrong with reducing female people to boobs, gams, and beaver.

description: Uncertain but surely formed within English; etymons may include game or gammon.

entries.meaning: Collective noun used to refer to a group of whales, or rarely also of porpoises; a pod.
examples: Upon getting into a "gam" of whales, this boat, together with that of one of the mates, pulled for a single whale that was seen at a distance from the others, and succeeded in getting square up to their victim unperceived.

entries.meaning: (by extension) A social gathering of whalers (whaling ships).
examples: There is still that yearning for news from Nantucket that there was when the whale-ships stopped for a gam out in the far-distant Pacific Ocean  […]

verbs.description: gam (third-person singular simple present gams, present participle gamming, simple past and past participle gammed)

entries.meaning: (nautical, transitive, intransitive) To pay a social visit on another ship at sea.
(US, dialect) To engage in social intercourse anywhere.
